habitat_description:
The sierra night lizard is found in western Arizona, southern Utah, southern Nevada, and southern California. In Mexico, the range of this species extends into southwestern Sonora and Baja California (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003). Several reports on populations in Arizona are now recognized as populations of Xantusia arizonae, Xantusia bezyi, and Xantusia wigginsi (Leavitt et al. 2007; Papenfuss et al. 2001; Sinclair et al. 2004).

The areas this lizard occupies are characterized as arid and semiarid such as desert, sagebrush and blackbrush shrubland, chaparral, hardwood woodland, and conifer woodland. This is a species that burrows in or using soil and leaf litter. In particular, this lizard is found among yuccas, cacti, and agaves. Also found in rock outcroppings, crevices, bark of foothill pines, and under logs (Stebbins 2003).

Associated with plants such as agaves, yuccas, and various cacti. Found in pinyon-juniper habitat, sagebrush-blackbrush, and chaparral-oak (Stebbins 2003).
